comments.text:
I have a different take on the 9070 vs 9070 XT take.
While 9% increase on price for 13% more performance seems very obvious which is superior in value, it's actually a very small difference, and the 9070 XT also consumes considerably more power at 100W extra, which doesn't seem like a lot, but that is ~40% more power going from the 9070 to the 9070 XT. There's also the heat comes with it, but without data, not sure how that plays out.
Depending on electricity prices, which are insane at the moment, that price to performance gap will quickly shrink, if not put the 9070 ahead in value within a year if there is heavy usage.
Personally, I'd go with the 9070 as I can absolutely see that working out better in the long run.

RX9070 is not a real product, it's just selling defective 9070XT dies at the biggest price AMD can do - and AMD has no intention of selling good 9070XT dies as 9070s. Basically, the price shows the TSMC process is doing really well and most dies are good to go for full 9070XTs.

comments.author: @erejnion

comments.text:
That's not just AMD, Nvidia and Intel do that too and this practice has been going on for decades.
Naming is just that, a naming, and a whole lot of products share the same chip model. 

I mean, 960 GTX and 950 GTX are both using the game GM206 GPU, but the 950 has less functionnal cores. Same goes for the 2060, 2060 Super and 2070, which all share the same TU106 GPU. 
The exact same thing goes for CPUs, where you can find chips sold at a higher price because they have a higher overclocking potential for example, just like the KS variants of the K chips in the Intel lineup. 

And that's not to fool the consumer, that just how it works.

First, they design a chip and then ask TSMC to engrave it on a wafers. The wafers produced contains dozens of the same dies aligned next to eachother, and some dies are just better quality than others. Some are gold tier and some are just good for the trash bin, none are identical. Then, AMD, Intel, or Nvidia, depending on how the quality scale ranges between the best and the worst die produced, will decide how much GPU/CPU tiers they will make with that chip.
That's how it works, that's how it has always worked.
In other words, manufacturers are not making fake products with the defective they have, because it works in reverse. They decide how many products each series will have depending on how sucessful the chips are on the waffles.

Nothing new under the sun. 
The only difference is that, this year, there is only one chip that has been produced and released by AMD in the RDN4 line-up, the Navi 48. At least for now. And that, after the engraving has been done, and the die have been tested, AMD decided for two main tiers of performance levels, which resulted in two different product names.
comments.author: @alexandrejude1306

comments.text:
@alexandrejude1306  Binning different products from the same chip is done by everybody.

What AMD specifically likes to do is make FAKE products - bin as few chips for them as possible, without any intention of long-term supply. I guess you really don't remember Ryzen 3300X. It existed for a couple of months or so before it sold out and AMD never ever restocked it.

comments.text:
I don't think the 9070 is getting enough credit. It's very similar performance wise to the 9070 XT (only ~12% average) and it's much more efficient which really does matter if you live in the UK like I do and have crazy electricity prices. The XT has a TDP of 304W and the non XT is getting almost the same FPS but doing so at 220W which is unreal. Also the fact that it doesn't require a PSU upgrade for people who already have 600W/700W PSU's in their machines.

I got a 9070 Pulse for £539 (it was £525 first batch but missed out, but still very close to MSRP) I couldn't even get a GRE for that price. When you take into account that the same Pulse XT variant has gone from £569 to £629 that's almost £100 difference for very little gain.

comments.text: Exactly this. I don't understand why many aren't looking at it this way. Great GPU for lower wattage power supplies is a huge bonus. It would have been nice if this GPU was priced a bit lower, but it's not that big of a deal others are making this out to be.

comments.author: @Abcgum64

comments.text: You're beyond the efficiency area of your PSU. That will age it faster than it should. With a 650W PSU you should max out in the 300-400W range of total wattage. Your GPU uses that by itself and it can use up to about 450W. Check out Cybenetics tests. They test and certify PSUs and have many test results on their site and the owner also runs Hardware Busters which also has PSU tests. They might have tested your PSU so you could look at the efficiency graph for it on their website. A high quality 750W PSU should be fine but it depends how power hungry your CPU is as well. Just because it seems to be doing OK so far doesn't mean it is happy pushing that much wattage through it. The components will run hotter the more load it has to take which will degrade them. Do you have a PSU tester so you know it's actually running fine? I heard Dr.Power testers are good. @سوريا_الجديدة

Of course you can power limit an XT down to similar efficiency, but then these cards are effectively the exact same price-to-performance. Giving this card a mediocre review versus the XT is misleading to people who will walk into a store or see it available online when the XT is out of stock. They should be rated the same, with the 9070 getting points for efficiency and the XT getting points for price-to-performance.

comments.text:
The 9070 XT undervolts extremely well, while the 9070 overclocks extremely well. There's really not much difference between the two cards when it comes to hardware.

It's like the 5070 vs. the 4070 Super. Once of the complaints about the 5070 is that it's not power efficient, but the Zotac non-OC model uses fewer watts than the 4070 Super and still put out about 4% more FPS. The OC models, on the other had, have tons of extra watts dumped into them to get 2% higher performance than the Zotac, making them far less efficient.

It's basically just the default settings of the cards that are weird. As long as you're willing to undervolt or overclock, all three of the new cards are noticeably more efficient than older cards.

comments.text:
I think you drew a bad conclusion honestly, and really...the cost per frame charts and conclusions drawn from there, other than the MSRP one, are moot, as the pricing is a shitshow around the globe. They're not wrong...but pretty irrelevant, though I understand why they're there.

Back to why I think both cards have a place...the 9070 is sitting at the peak of the efficiency curve, it strikes the perfect balance between power and performance. 
The XT throws everything out the window and draws as much power as it can for better performance without becoming ridiculous. 

I am going to try and compile multiple result sets, but my gut is saying that AMD knew exactly what they were doing here.
On average, it seems like the XT consumes ~36% more power, but is only 10-15% faster depending on the scenario.
When you take into account lower cooling needs, the size of some models(dual fan models), the lower thermals which could lead to quieter operation for the non XT and the same VRAM buffer size ,I think once prices settle, the 9070 will find its place. 
It's definitely not a miss.

comments.text:
Really need a deep dive with cooperation from the chipset drivers manufacturers. Call it a coalition of consumer integrity or something.

For example, the software driver reports to its respected card when a GPU is turned on/serial number is shared(by way of terms and conditions already). 

This can be compared with the time the card reported sold at point of sale, and how long until the card was actually used. The silicon is serialized to each AIB as well, and can be tracked to retailers. 

Essentially, data from the time a manufacturing, to the time the consumer began using the card reported by the driver. This can then be investigated to see to see if the card was purchased for use, or to be resold.

 If the time lapsed from sale to use is too high(minus a few outliers), the manufacturers and retails can have the data to work together for the consumer. 

Understandable, the manufacturers got their money already, and so did the retailers. If unwilling to benefit the actual consumer, legislation may need to be required to prevent retailers to take any available measures to prevent electronic algorithm purchases, and limit access to the retailers point of sale and inventory system.

For example, can search online for YouTube Livestream GPU live stock updates. Can watch these algorithms at work searching retailers for stock in less than a second. There's no oversight preventing the search, or from also buying once found. These live streams demonstrate the ability for automated shopping and purchasing. 

There are also new apps for sale allowing this to happen. Essentially, "here's my payment information, and go buy it once it's found." 

This is a serious issue as the algorithm is essentially creating its own market, and replacing the retailers--effectively changing the traditional retailers, and turning it into a distribution channel wholesaler, instead. The 'bot inventory' is now the retailers.

At this time, it doesn't seem anything to mitigate the automated purchasing of items with only the intent to sale at a markup price. 

At this time, hopefully an argument can be made in the new algorithm and automated data processing segment of the consumer market. This is going to get worse, and need oversight and integrity between manufacturing and consumer.

TLDR/ recognition of a potential legaslative argument to prevent future automated point of sale purchasing--not intended for the original buyer.

comments.text: $50 USD MSRP = $96 AUD "MSRP". You work it out by doing 50 / 0.63 (exchange rate) * 1.1 (GST) * 1.1 (customs duty - the retailer has to pay this to the ABF so of course it'll get passed on to the customer, but this isn't retailer profiteering, it's our very own "tariffs" - the US isn't the only one doing those). So if the difference between 9070 and 9070 XT is $90 AUD, that's roughly in line with the US difference.

As a consumer I find the price of the 9070 frustrating. It's the card I'd likely buy if it was priced sensibly. But of course saving $50 on something I'll own and use for years is totally pointless.
However, if I would buy it if it was sensibly priced I imagine a lot of others would too. Demand would go from next to nothing to massive and I do wonder if the price is in part because they wouldn't be able to supply that level of demand if they're getting good yields on the chips being good enough for XT cards. In which case I get it. But I'm a customer not a shareholder so I'm still left frustrated either way.

I also partly expect they had the 9070 XT earmarked at $650, the 9070 at the $550 is it is and the 9060 XT will be $450. So if they dropped it's price they'd then also have to drop the price of the 9060 XT or then that card doesn't make sense. But they'll have a lot more 9060 XTs to sell.

Hopefully if they don't sell we see the price drop without them just instantly selling out.

comments.text:
This is obviously a "upsell" model. On top of that, it's likely most of the chips going in it are not even imperfect 9070 XTs, but actual full fat Navi48 intentionally cut down. Since, later on, they will actually get actual "savaged" Navi48 XTs... and that's probably at around the same time they'll start dropping it's price to be more relative to it's performance delta vs the 9070 XT.

A win for AMD, but a muted middle finger to the consumer, at least temporarily.

PS: It's weird you have so much negativity or ambivalence in your titles, even with good products in these cards, you guys having  probably the most negative sounding review of the 9070 XT from at least a dozen reviews I've read/watched. Even GN started off hinting at 9070s chart-topping efficiency. In contrast to your title or the amateurish remarks about RDNA4 "being less efficient than Blackwell" (or getting the die sizes wrong, in claming Navi48 is a bigger chip than GB203) in the 9070 XT review. On top of that, with zero testing of multi-monitor, mixed refresh multi-monitor, framerate locked efficiency and others (which as per legendary German reviewers at Igor'sLab and ComputerBase, blow anything nVidia has out of the water... which is also a much more realistic scenario to play games at than FurMark torture tests or playing random games as if you're benchmarking them). Which are almost all, insanely huge leaps made by AMD in such departments, at least as in "day1 driver testing results", not FineWine(tm).

Speaking of which, the only huge AMD FineWine improvement I'm expecting is to RDNA4's RT/PT performance., as well as obviously launching their finished denoisers and and neural rendering APIs. Just look at 3DMark's DXR feature test, 9070XT barely matches the 7900XTX, while in actual heavy RT/PT tests, the jump in performance over 7900XTX is huge (baring in mind it's also 64CU/Ray Accelerators vs 96), that obviously isn't right and neither are most of the productivity results, since HIP/ROCm support for Navi48 isn't quite ready yet. Check DeepSeek R1 Inference benchmarking, there's clearly a lot of potential for AI workhorse there as well. But this, most likely is something AMD will only fully address once RDNA5/UDNA is here. They'll most likely want to cash in on the "prosumer" GPU market, that nVidia has already courted since the TITAN days and now xx90 cards. AMD has already shown to want such markets, with stuff like ThreadRipper.

comments.text: Efficiency matters to PCMR snobs. That conversation should be more prominent in the analysis. Tech lovers do not want to be using 50% more electricity for 10% more performance. That just feels like buying old technology. Perhaps a good metaphor might be buying a muscle car with a V8. You might pay a little more for a little more performance and technically you win a 0-60 run but getting a modern four cylinder turbo is nearly as fast with way less gas. Back to GPUs, we're talking about the difference between setting a few graphics settings to high instead of ultra on RX 9070 to basically match the faster card and WAY less power draw. RX 9070 feels like you are buying a modern product and XT feels like you are buying a muscle car from the mid-2000s. Hope this metaphor is not lost on readers.

comments.text:
In Germany or maybe all of EU, the MSRP got dropped for the 9070 and 9070 XT, normally they should've been 100€ more expensive than in $, so 650€and 699€, but AMD dropped it to 629€ and 689€.
I personally snacked a 9070 and I think I will be quite happy with it as a upgrade from a 3070.
1. I only care for 1440p 60 fps and I don't think that the 12ish% that the XT is worth it, because the Games wher a non XT struggels the XT isn't far off or is also struggeling.
2. I only have a 650w psu, and while my watt estimate for my PC with a XT should be around is like 488watt, the power spikes the XT make me worry. So to be save I would also have to buy a new PSU which is roughly another 100€ + the 60€ that the XT costs more.
3. Power Draw... I feel like that's a thing that many people don't consider... the Xt gives like 12% better performance for like 30ish % more power draw. So in the long run, the XT will just cost me more and more. So 100€ for a PSU, 60€ for the XT instead of non Xt and then it could cost me another 40-50€+ per year more because of the power draw. And all of that for 12% better performance.
So yeah... I think I will be quite happy with a 9070.

comments.text: I think it’s priced this way because this isn’t their original intended pricing. I think they intended for the 9070 to be $599 and the XT $699. With slimmer margins they felt it was better to make the non-XT a slightly worse value to try and maintain as much profit margin as possible. At the end of the day, the non-XT costs the same to build in the backend. Once things settle and the economy’s of scale is rolling we’ll probably see a $499 price point. That or tariffs will make everything more expensive, we’ll see

comments.text:
My biggest issue with the 9070/9070XT cards is the size. All of them but a select few are massive triple fan models. There's no reason for the 9070 to be so massive considering the lower power draw compared to the XT. I have a Coolermaster NR200 that barely fits my RX6800 reference card with the power cables attached. All the 9070/9070XT models are right on the line of just barely fitting and I would likely need to get some kind of 90° adapter to be able to clear the power connectors. Nvidia partners have multiple 5070 models available with a dual fan design that would be perfect for the NR200. But no way I'm buying a GPU with 12GB VRAM to replalce a card with 16GB.

But it also seems as if XFX were the only ones to drop cards online at MSRP here in the US for both the 9070 and 9070XT. Everything else is $100-200 over. The MSRP cards were sold out in seconds. The cards wtih inflated prices are still available 30 mins later. Even some of the 5070 models with higher pricing are still in stock. So, it would seem we're hitting the point where people are at least hesitating before paying well over MSRP for these. That's a step in the right direction, haha.

comments.text: cost per frame for higher end cards should always decrease, NOT increase. This makes perfect sense. In fact, cost per frame should always keep constant. I don't buy the "premium" bs. It's a product, the number of fps makes it premium, not the cost. You should be paying proportionally more, not exponentially. Even the opposite of that, as I mentioned at the beginning. Richer people will be able to enjoy more because the cost per frame will be more desirable and more higher end products will be sold. It's the greed of manufacturers that makes the situation the opposite. And please, don't sell me the automotive industry cr*p, it's a consumer product, Veyron isn't, it's not point A to point B product. The parallel should be AC unit sizing for example. You don't pay premium for a 7kW unit 4x than you pay for 3.5kW. Graphics is graphics, the effects are the same, it's just the speed. Apples to apples. The manufacturers should be called out. Additionally, because they have ways of making scrap silicon wafer usable, so they make up for the normalized prize of good wafer samples.

Cards grow in factories.

Get ready.

comments.text: The AMD pricing strategy of this card is actually very simple. They produce little bad chips for RX 9070. If you sell a lot of cards like NVIDIA you would just price RX 9070 XT much higher, have bigger margin. AMD needs to be competitive so they price the cards not as the market dictates, but closer to the production costs, so their price looks good. At least for the launch... Retailers that know the original launch prices say RX 9070 XT was discounted 20%, 9070 - 15% (from the January shipment). All these cards will settle to their realistic market prices in few months... This is why "recommendations" based on MSRP are very misleading. Better have a separate segment every month - what's wroth buying right now based on real prices.

comments.text:
I bought an XFX (3 fan) 7600 to go from an RX 580. I was surprised to see the VRAM temps in comparison to the 580, where in this case it was 10°C more at idle and then 15 to 20 degrees more during usage. 

I see the exact same thing on this review with the 9070 from 3 different manufacturers. Why? And is this a new trend that could cause issues? I know a GPU can withstand up to 120°C degrees or whatever, but we also know heat is the actual destructor of hardware, not "wear and tear". I know 86°C is still "ok-ish" but considering the junction is 53 to 59... 86 seems excessive. And what if I'm in a place with no strong AC and it's a 40°C day outside. Is the VRAM going to be 100°C? 

I'll grant I'm ignorant on this matter so the question might be really stupid, but that's why I'm asking. To know about it, because I haven't seen this behavior before these "newer cards".

comments.text:
What should be blaring to everybody is that the gains of this latest generation right down the stack has been incredibly underwhelming.

If you look from the RTX 5080 all the way down to say the RX 7800 XT, there isn't an awful lot between the cards, they are basically 1440p cards with marginal performance advantages over the other.

In a real word scenario you wouldn't even notice the difference between them.

The real disappointment is that no card on the market, currently, is really delivering what can be considered true 4K performance.

4K has been out on the mainstream for 13 years now.

This isn't a win for anybody.

Roll on 6000 series and not with baited breath either.

comments.text:
Hello. I don't often offer feedback or comments but you asked for them at the end of the video and after ruminating on what I watched unfold I have at least something.
At various times in the video I noticed you would say something while going over performance and mentioning last generation, although you don't seem to be calculating things proportionally. It was really rather strange and it reached a point where I was alt tabbing, pulling up numbers myself and calculating it to get the data I needed. For a video review and one clocking in at around 16 & 1/2 minutes this took more time to get the necessary info than needed.
The selection of cards benchmarked & displayed were odd and seeing the lower ends omitted from some sections was disappointing; I would assume you have done so because they are no longer in production perhaps?
Your cost breakdowns and comments on the price seem fair, largely I think most people will agree, some of it is subjective, some of it is objective. The objective metrics come out a little weaker given the poor understanding of the product but at the very least track if somewhat accidentally against information you've missed.

Finally, outside of the above feedback in relation to benchmarking & information display/crunching:
I feel as though you've tapped into a feedback loop as a reviewer. The very same feedback loop that AMD had during previous generations of RDNA, I've looked at these cards and the TDP cut the 9070 base model has appeals to a certain segment of the market. Noting the number of CUs and the TDP versus past generations, there's definitely a reasonable uplift and a space in the market for the product. As a reviewer of hardware, it's easy to be blinded by performance and numbers. When you're presented with nvidia charts it can be somewhat easy to forget about relativity & proportional performance but it is still there. Overall this video has taken around 1.5 hours (including typing this feedback to get through) and I still need to go elsewhere to really get an idea of the 9070 as a product.

I hope you have a pleasant day.

Here in Portugal the cheapest 9070 i found is 645€, the cheapest 9070XT is 770€. Cheapest 5070 is 670€, cheapest 5070 Ti is 1040€.

So in this context the 9070XT is 20% more expensive than the 9070 while delivering 8% more FPS (1440p results) and consuming some 15-20% more power. 

I never saw a new 7900XT below the 800€ mark and 600€ used, just as i have never seen a 7900XTX below 1000€ new/750€ used. Nvidia are all sky high expensive as you all can imagine so i would say the 9070, in this region, is the best buy right now for anyone building a 1440p setup by far.

comments.text:
Why is nobody talking about the Nvidia gpu's struggling with 1%/low and frametime stability vs AMD? You can see it in many games even in these simple fps bar graphs, but it becomes very clear when comparing the actual frametime graphs on Nvidia vs AMD gpu's.

And it's not only on RTX 50 series, it's the same with 40 series. AMD (both 7000 and 9000 series) has way better 1%/lows and much more stable frametimes across the popular game suites.

Before you call me names, just go and look the actual frametime graphs on comparison videos. It has been hiding in plain sight because no one pays attention, no one talks about it.
comments.author: @Johnny-fw9xj

comments.text:
Ps. It's not as evident in (averaged) benchmark scores, but then again benchmarks have nothing to do with actual gaming experience.

But when you compare frametimes when actually playing a game, it's easy to see how the frametime graphs are very different.

JayTwoCents even said in his 9070 review that he thinks it is the "best gaming experience" of all the gpu's since the start of his YT channel. And by that he means how smooth the games run, and how smooth the gaming experience is.

It's definitely interesting for a wider scope of the population. But not for enthusiasts or reviewers.

It is the buy for me, personally.

comments.text:
Hi Steve - yes the pricing difference is crazy, but there are some important reasons people might still choose the 9070 over the XT: 
- Size - there is no XT model that's 2-fan other than the XFX one that's about as fat as a bus. So SFF cases will sometimes not fit them. I love my Sugo 13 and don't really want to change it, so the 9070 is the only one that might just fit.
- Power - you noted efficiency but the other thing is that it may mean people can avoid upgrading their PSU - which if you add the cost of that it totally changes the value proposition overall. 
- Monitor - 1440 is much more common than 4k, so anyone not wanting or able to upgrade the monitor will see a much smaller difference in the value of going to XT.

comments.text: My HTPC is also an SG13 and I didn't find a 9070 that looked like it would fit. comments.text: @PepsiMagt  it absolutely does work like that. You can add as many vram modules of varying sizes as you want without altering bandwidth as long as the memory controller supports it. The only instance where you're forced to double the capacity is with a clamshell design, because you're mirroring the vram modules to the other side of the pcb. That's the only instance where a doubling is required to increase capacity, but everything else is fair game.

comments.text:
I guess it depends on what you want as an "upgrade". If you've got a 7900 XT or 7900 XTX and you don't consider the 9070 XT an upgrade to the cards to the 7900XT, then the cards you could "upgrade" into are the 4080/Super, the 5070 Ti, the 5080, the 4090, or the 5090. Unless you're going to get a 4090/5090, those other cards offer between 13-27% (for the 7900XT) improvement for well over $1000USD, and 9% improvement (to go from 7900 XTX to 5080). If you feel like spending more than $2000, you can get 20-30% improvement if you get a 90 series card.

If you've got a 6000 series card, there's upgrades depending on how you feel about improvement. The 9070XT is 19% faster than the 6950 XT, 25% faster than the 6900 XT, 30% faster than the 6800 XT, and 38% faster than the 6800. The 9070 is 8%, 16%, 22%, and 32% faster than each of those cards in order. That's all in rasterization performance, and cheaper that most of the MSRP's for those other cards, too.

If you care about RT, the 9070 and 9070 XT both are faster than the 7900 XTX at RT, so that's just a straight up upgrade over any other AMD card. If you care about FSR 4, that's a straight upgrade over FSR 3.1 without argument.

I personally don't care about RT or fake frames or fake resolutions, myself. But, I do think the 9070 and the 9070 XT are pretty solid raster upgrades from the 6800 or 6900. If you had a 7900 XT or 7900 XTX, then yea, no, not real upgrades, except for RT and FSR 4 (if you care about those).

comments.text:
​@ 
That latency translates in a single threaded performance hit of 1fps at 200fps in the real world, it's nothing. Meanwhile for just a 22% increase in price you got 50% more cores and double the L3 cache which is massive if you do any amount of multitasking. Less delay when switching tasks, smoother framepacing, more CPU to do background tasks... For just another 100$ it was a no brainer to get the 5900x.

The 5800x also didn't make sense since you could've just gotten a 9900k 2 years earlier for only 50$ more at $500. Sure it's maybe 10% slower, but still 8C/16T. Why wait 2 years for a CPU that's only marginally faster? To save $50? Remember when people were mad at Intel for releasing a 500$ CPU? Meanwhile people were lining up to buy a 10% faster CPU for 50$ less 2 years later. It's walking over dollars to pick up pennies. Looking back, the 9900k was actually a good deal.

If the 5800x launched at 400$ it would've been better, at 350$ it would've been amazing. Same thing with the 5600x, 300$ was just too much for that CPU. Instead you could've enjoyed a mildly slower 8700K for over 3 years for just 50$ more. Great CPUs, just disappointing pricing except for the Ryzen 9's. 550$ for 12 fast cores was a good deal in 2020. 750$ for 16 less so, but that's to be expected with the most premium product.

@100organicfreshmemes5  12GB VRAM is plenty for a card of the 5070s power level. Did you notice that the only time it failed on VRAM in this video was when it was was running ridiculous settings at a high resolution? comments.text:
@TheInevitron  RDNA4 is plenty for raytracing. Did you notice the only games it has any trouble running are poorly optimized games and/or with pathtracing like Cyberpunk and Black Myth Wukong? Even if it had equal RT performance to RTX cards it'd still be losing 40% or more of its FPS running pathtracing in games like that. Who cares about RT when you lose 25% of your FPS and it barely looks different in 95% of games anyway?

For extremely rare situations where its RT performance isn't playable, just turn it off. Is that really such a gamebreaker? "Oh no, I get 25% higher FPS and now the lighting looks the same as every other game I play!"

comments.author: @TheInevitron

comments.text:
@TheInevitron  I'm using the same absurd argument as you, just flipped to be talking about how RT doesn't really matter instead of VRAM not really mattering.

Main difference is without VRAM, games will struggle to run. Without Nvidia RT performance, you get a marginally lower FPS or a much better FPS and marginally lower image quality by simply turning RT off. The GTX 1660 in my brothers' old PC literally can't run Ghostrunner at low settings, RT off, 1080p because it's VRAM limited. Textures fail to load and it turns into a 15~ FPS slideshow. Meanwhile my RX 6750XT ran it around 100 FPS at 1440p native, max settings (minus RT, which barely looks any different).

That's especially true since GPUs aren't adding more VRAM to cards, which means developers won't be requiring significantly more VRAM. At absolute worst, anyone with a 5070 will just have to turn a higher percentage of new games' textures down one notch.

For the really intensive stuff that requires more VRAM, the 5070's too weak to run games on those settings anyway. comments.text:
​ @RX7800XTBenchmarks  

What nonsense are you spouting about? You are telling me you don't feel the difference between real frames and generated frames? It's like the biggest drawback of frame gen so far.

Your input latency doesn't get any better than your real framerate. So even if you're getting 120 FPS via frame gen, your input latency won't be any better than what you can achieve with 60 fps [or whatever your real framerate is].

Frame gen is in this aspect, worse than even upscaling. And will never amount to actual high frame rate.


As for TAA looking worse, that doesn't excuse upscaling either. If your GPU needs to rely on upscaling to maintain good framerate, then the GPU is simply not good enough. Upscaled image might look better than native res with TAA. But that's comparing constipation with diarrhoea. Both are bad. 

You have a point about better RT performance. But I don't see how the RT performance is decent in any of these GPUs [that includes 5070 and 5070 Ti]. It's just bad.

comments.author: @fwabble

comments.text: Cost per frame isn't THE metric. If DLSS 3/4 with its internal high-quality DLAA anti-aliasing brings you identical image quality compared to AMD with native rendering and temporal anti-alising, aka TAA, which itself softens the image more than Nvidia's DLAA since TAA is really a barebones form of anti-alising, then native rendering suddenly doesn't matter as much. Cost per frame at native rendering is still the most important metric to look for, but there isn't just one metric that matters. The only reason why native rendering should be the most important topic in reviews is that it's the most simple for the average buyer to understand and lacks any mostly subjective variables like image quality. Comparing Nvidia with DLSS toggled on vs. AMD at native wouldn't be good journalism unless there is some disclaimer and explanation of why that metric was chosen.

comments.text: Too many people still dont understand that TDP is not what a GPU needs to run, it's just a spec the manufacturer decides on.  You can run a GPU at almost any power level(within some limits of course).  Undoubtedly AMD will be throwing some of these same GPU's into laptops that never run them at more than 100w.  The 9070XT isn't some locked in 300w, that's just the default stock spec.  You can undervolt and underclock it a bit to save a bunch of power.  The bigger downside of a higher TDP stock spec is that it forces the graphics card to be more robust with cooling and VRMs and whatnot, increasing size and cost.  Very bad trend if you ask me.  They used to give us lower TDP so that we could have normal sized graphics cards, and then have OPTIONAL large/robust ones for overclockers at a premium.  Gotta juice those review benchmarks nowadays, though. smh

My concern about these overclocked cards is the VRM and VRAM longevity, the GPU can handle high heat. If a brand uses the backplate to cool the memory avoid it, it may seem better than other models, because lowers the GPU and memory temp, while lowering the fan speed and cooking the VRM in the process. I hate when reviewers complaining about that manufacturers don't use the backplate for cooling, most of them if they do only cool the VRM and some brainlessly cool the GPU and VRAM and you get a 90°C backplate.

comments.text:
@DanielTaylor-br5cm  Not now, yep. But after 6+ months of production, salvaged die will start piling up.

Hell, they might even release a "RX 9070 GRE", with 48 CUs (and maybe 192bit/12GB?), for something like $449 or less, with 9070 dropping $499 before it, at least on paper).

But there's also a rumor of a 9070 XTX or such, with a binned die/higher clocks and 24Gbps GDDR6 coming in Q2 this year, to further chip away at 5080 sales and pre-empt early "Super"  refreshes from nVidia. Which might mean their dies are in better shape than I thought.

Still, people have to remember, the die itself is actually bigger than Navi 31's graphics chiplet (357mm/2 vs 304mm/2),  but the Navi31 dies is obviously useless with it's neighbouring 4-6x 64bit/16MB chace memory chiplets.
What I'm trying to say is Navi31's main 5/4nm die, in a vacuum, is smaller hence easier to produce without defects than Navi48, YET we've still seen both 84CU cuts (7900XTX) and 80CU cuts (7900GRE) from it, which most likely (at least later in it's production cycle) were not artificially cut perfect dies, but in a big part, salvaged ones.
